title: Text fields
description: Text fields allow users to enter text into a UI. They typically appear in forms and dialogs.

contentChunks.htmlValue: There are two types of text fields: filled and outlined.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Filled text field
2. Outlined text field
contentChunks.altText: Side by side view two types of text fields, filled and outlined

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Resources

TypeLinkStatus
DesignDesign kit (Figma)Available
M2 guideline – Text fieldsAvailable
ImplementationMDC-AndroidAvailable
Jetpack ComposeAvailable
FlutterIn progress
WebPlanned

Takeaways

  • Text fields should stand out and indicate that users can input information.
  • Text field states should be clearly differentiated from one another.
  • Text fields should make it easy to understand the requested information and to address any errors.
What's new
• Color: New color mappings and compatibility with dynamic color

contentChunks.footer: Text fields have new color mappings.
contentChunks.altText: Image of a filled and outlined text field using the new M3 color mappings

contentChunks.htmlValue:

Filled text field color

Color values are implemented through design tokens. For design, this means working with color values that correspond with tokens. For implementation, a color value will be a token that references a value. Learn more about design tokens.

Filled text field error states

Error states are visual representations used to communicate the status of a component or interactive element. An error message can display instructions on how to fix it. Error messages are displayed below the text field as supporting text until fixed.

contentChunks.footer: Filled and outlined text fields.
contentChunks.altText: A side by side view of a filled and a outlined text field

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage
Use a text field when someone needs to enter text into a UI, such as filling in contact or payment information.

contentChunks.footer: Contact form using outlined text fields.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of contact form with several text fields.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
There are two types of text fields:

  1. Filled text fields
  2. Outlined text fields

Both types of text fields use a container to provide a visual cue for interaction and provide the same functionality,

contentChunks.footer: 1. Filled text field.
contentChunks.altText: Side by side view of a populated and unpopulated filled text field.

contentChunks.footer: 2. Outlined text field.
contentChunks.altText: Side by side view of a populated and unpopulated outlined text field.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Outlined text fields

Outlined text fields have less visual emphasis than filled text fields. When they appear in places like forms (where many text fields are placed together) their reduced emphasis helps simplify the layout.

contentChunks.footer: Login screen with outlined text fields.
contentChunks.altText: App screen with a focused outlined text field.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Choosing text fields

Both types of text field provide the same functionality, so the type of text field you use can depend on style alone.

Choose the type that:

  • Works best with your app’s visual style
  • Best accommodates the goals of your UI
  • Is most distinct from other components (like buttons) and surrounding content

contentChunks.footer: Mobile form using filled text fields.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of a contact form with several filled text fields.

contentChunks.footer: The same mobile form using outlined text fields.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of a contact form with several outlined text fields.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Using both types of text field on the same screen

If both types of text field are used in a UI, they should be used consistently within different sections, and not intermixed within the same region. For example, you could use outlined text fields in one section and filled text fields in another.

contentChunks.footer: When using both types of text fields in a UI, separate them by region.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of a contact form with several filled text fields, and an open dialog on top using an outlined text field.

contentChunks.footer: When using both types of text fields, don't use both next to each other or within the same form.
contentChunks.altText: MMobile UI of a contact form with a mix of outlined and filled text fields.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Outlined text field

1. Container outline (enabled)
2. Label text (empty)

contentChunks.altText: Diagram of filled text field indicating the 10 parts of its anatomy

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Containers

Containers improve the discoverability of text fields by creating contrast between the text field and surrounding content.

Fill and stroke
A text field container has a fill and a stroke (either around the entire container, or just the bottom edge). The color and thickness of a stroke can change to indicate when the text field is active. 

Rounded corners
The container of an outlined text field has rounded corners, while the container of a filled text field has rounded top corners and square bottom corners.

contentChunks.footer: Text field containers.
contentChunks.altText: Side by side view of the containers of a filled and outlined text field.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Label text

Label text informs users about what information is requested for a text field. Every text field should have a label.

Label text should be aligned with the input text, and always visible. It can be placed in the middle of a text field, or rest near the top of the container.

Label text shouldn't be truncated or take up multiple lines. Keep it short, clear, and fully visible.

contentChunks.footer: Label text should always be visible. When the field is selected, the label text moves from the middle of the text field to the top.
contentChunks.altText: Side by side view of the label texts of a filled and outlined text field.

contentChunks.footer: Don’t truncate label text. Keep it short, clear, and fully visible.
contentChunks.altText: Text field with very long label text, too long to display fully display inside the text field container.

contentChunks.footer: Label text shouldn’t take up multiple lines.
contentChunks.altText: Text field with very long label text, too long to display fully display inside the text field container.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Adjacent label

A text field doesn't require a label if the field's purpose is indicated by a separate, adjacent label. 

Adjacent labels should be aligned to the leading edge of the text field container.

contentChunks.footer: Text fields with adjacent labels.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of a contact form with label texts placed outside and on top of the text fields.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Required text indicator

To indicate that a field is required, display an asterisk (*) next to the label text and mention in supporting text that the asterisks indicate required fields.

  • If some fields are required, indicate all required ones
  • If most fields are required, indicate optional fields by displaying the word “optional” in parentheses next to the label text
  • If required text has a particular color, that color should also be used for the asterisk

contentChunks.footer: Required text with asterisk.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of a contact form showing supporting text below the text field, indicating an input is required.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Input text

Input text is text the user has entered into a text field.

Text fields can display user input text in the following ways:

  • Single line text fields display only one line of text
  • Multi-line text fields grow to accommodate multiple lines of text
  • Text areas are fixed-height fields

contentChunks.footer: Input text in a filled text field.
contentChunks.altText: Text field with populated input text.

contentChunks.footer: In single-line fields, as the cursor reaches the right field edge, text longer than the input line automatically scrolls left. Single-line fields are not suitable for collecting long responses. For those, use a multi-line text field or text area instead.
contentChunks.altText: Text field with very long input text that scrolls sideways.

contentChunks.footer:
Overflow text causes the text field to expand (shifting screen elements downward), and text wraps onto a new line.
 
These fields initially appear as single-line fields, which is useful for compact layouts that need to be able to accommodate large amounts of text.
contentChunks.altText: Text field with very long input text that wraps into a second line, expanding the text field container.

contentChunks.footer:
Text areas are taller than text fields and wrap overflow text onto a new line. They are a fixed height and scroll vertically when the cursor reaches the bottom of the field.
 
The large initial size indicates that longer responses are possible and encouraged.
 
These should be used instead of multi-line fields on the web. Ensure the height of a text area fits within mobile screen sizes.
contentChunks.altText: Text area with enough space to allow a very long input text to wraps into a second line without the need to expand the container.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Prefix text

Text fields can contain prefix text such as a currency symbol.

contentChunks.footer: A text field with a currency symbol text prefix.
contentChunks.altText: Text field with a currency prefix before the input text.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Suffix text

Text fields can contain suffix text such as unit of measurement or email domain.

contentChunks.footer: A text field with a grading scale as suffix.
contentChunks.altText: Text field with a suffix after the input text indicating a maximum input of one hundred.

contentChunks.footer: Text field with an email domain address suffix.
contentChunks.altText: Text field with a suffix after the input text indicating an email address.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Supporting text and character counter

Supporting text conveys additional information about the input field, such as how it will be used. It should ideally only take up a single line, though may wrap to multiple lines if required, and be either persistently visible or visible only on focus.

Character or word counters should be used if there is a character or word limit. They display the ratio of characters used and the total character limit.

contentChunks.footer: 1. Supporting text 2. Character counter
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of a sign up form indicating a invalid entry, and a hint on how to resolve as supporting text below the container.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Error text

For text fields that validate their content (such as passwords), replace supporting text with error text when applicable. Swapping supporting text with error text helps prevent new lines of text from being introduced into a layout, thus bumping content to fit it.

  • If only one error is possible, error text describes how to avoid the error
  • If multiple errors are possible, error text describes how to avoid the most likely error

contentChunks.footer: Swap supporting text with error text.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of a sign up form indicating a invalid entry, and a hint on how to resolve as supporting text below the container.

contentChunks.footer: Don't add error text in addition to supporting text, as their appearance will shift content.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of a sign up form indicating a invalid entry, showing the regular supporting text in addition to a hint how to resolve the error.

contentChunks.footer: Long errors can wrap to multiple lines if there isn't enough space to clearly describe the error. In this case, ensure padding between text fields is sufficient to prevent multi-lined errors from bumping layout content.
contentChunks.altText: Mobile UI of a sign up form indicating a invalid entry, showing a supporting text wrapping into two lines due to its length.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Icons & images

Icons in text fields are optional. Text field icons can describe valid input methods (such as a microphone icon), provide affordances to access additional functionality (such as clearing the content of a field), and can express an error.

Leading and trailing icons change their position based on LTR or RTL contexts.

Images that are 24dp in height can be placed inside of text fields. This image height allows for optimal top and bottom padding within the field and is consistent with the size recommendation for icons.

1. Icon signifier 
    Icon signifiers can describe the type of input a text field requires, and be touch targets for nested components. For example, a calendar icon may be tapped to reveal a date picker.
  2. Valid or error icon
    Iconography can indicate both valid and invalid inputs, making error states clear for colorblind users. 
  3. Clear icon
    Clear icons let users clear an entire input field. They appear only when input text is present.
  4. Voice input icon
    A microphone icon signifies that users can input characters using voice. 
  5. Dropdown icon
    A dropdown arrow indicates that a text field has a nested selection component.
  6. Image
    An image can help to contextualize data input. For example when a user is required to enter credit card information.

contentChunks.footer: 1. Icon signifier 2. Valid or error icon 3. Clear icon 4. Voice input icon 5. Dropdown icon 6. Image
contentChunks.altText: Side by side view of text fields with different icons and images as trailing elements within the container.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Read-only fields

Read-only text fields display pre-filled text that the user cannot edit. A read-only text field is styled the same as a regular text field and is clearly labeled as read-only.

contentChunks.footer: A filled read-only text field.
contentChunks.altText: Read only filled text field.

contentChunks.footer: An outlined read-only text field.
contentChunks.altText: Read only outlined text field.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Responsive layout

As layouts adapt to larger screens and form factors, apply flexible container dimensions to text fields. Set minimum and maximum values for margins, padding, and container dimensions as layouts scale so that typography adjusts for better reading experiences.

contentChunks.footer: Text fields can span the full width of the display on small screens, but should be bounded by flexible margins or other containers on larger screens.
contentChunks.altText: UI for creating a new album in a side by side view on mobile and tablet.

contentChunks.htmlValue: As text fields expand within fluid layouts, avoid maintaining fixed margins and typography properties because this can lead to extra long text fields. Text fields should not, for example, span the full width of a large screen.

contentChunks.footer: Don’t used fixed text field margins on large devices. Text fields shouldn’t span the full width of a large screen.
contentChunks.altText: Tablet UI with text fields spanning the complete width of the screen.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Density

Dense text fields enable users to scan and take action on large amounts of information.

contentChunks.footer: A form with dense text fields.
contentChunks.altText: Tablet UI with desne text field as part of event creation form.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
